title: Global ketchup consumption squeezed by trade row and millennial apathy
text:
Global demand for ketchup is being squeezed as both global warming and a trade row between the US and Canada takes a toll and millennials fall out of love with the red sauce.

Demand for the tomato condiment weakened as consumption in Canada – the world’s biggest importer – fell by a fifth in the first four months of 2019.

Canada’s annual intake of ketchup is more than 200,000 tonnes – equivalent to more than 5kg per person, or almost 13 standard 400g bottles a year. More than nine in 10 bottles consumed in Canada come from the US.

Meanwhile, younger shoppers are turning to healthy, fresh products instead as tastes change – and even the changing climate is thought to have played a part.
